content.text: **Completeness** is the converse of soundness: if a formula is valid (true in all interpretations), then our system can prove it. Nothing true escapes our proof methods.

content.definition: A proof system is complete if: whenever ⊨ φ (φ is valid), then ⊢ φ (φ is provable). Truth implies provability.

content.text: Soundness and completeness together mean our proof system perfectly matches semantic truth. ⊢ φ if and only if ⊨ φ. The syntactic notion (proof) and semantic notion (truth) coincide.

content.title: Soundness + Completeness
content.note: A sound and complete system captures exactly the valid formulas — no more, no less.

content.text: Kurt Gödel proved completeness for first-order logic in 1929. This was a major achievement: it shows that first-order logic has a proof system that can derive every valid formula.

content.question: What does completeness guarantee about a proof system?
options: Every valid formula can be proven
content.explanation: Completeness means every semantically valid formula is provable. Combined with soundness, this means provability and validity are the same thing.
